children.value: luma.gl contains a lot of classes and functions that might make new users wonder where to get started. luma.gl therefore organize classes and functions into groups, as shown in the following table and also in the folder structure of the source code
A set of classes covering all
. Currently luma.gl supports WebGL 2.0. These classes organize the WebGL2 API and makes it easy to work with in JavaScript.
A set of common classes across all 3D graphics applications. They are on a higher abstraction level than the WebGL API. luma.gl's signature
This folder contains a collection of geometric primitives extending from the base
. They can be used to create
created from simple geometries from the
Node.js and browser file loaders. Also enables using streams in browser.
A very simple browser event handling class used by luma.gl examples
luma.gl's internal shader module system and shader assembler utility
The heart of luma.gl is the

module, a set of JavaScript class wrappers covering all WebGL objects. From luma.gl v4,
After creating a context, perhaps with luma.gl's
function, you have can start instantiating luma.gl's WebGL2 classes:

class, represents a set of objects that is common in most 3D rendering libraries or engines. These objects are at higher abstraction levels than the actual WebGL objects and that can serve as the basic building blocks for most 3D applications.
- A renderable object with program, attributes, uniforms and other state required for rendering 3D objects on the screen
- Holds attributes and drawType for a primitive geometric object
- A simple animation loop that connects with browser's animation mechanism

-
* [`Object3D`](api-reference/core/object3d) - Base class, golds position, rotation, scale (TBD)
* [`Group`](api-reference/core/group) - Supports recursive travesal and matrix transformation
object holds a set of attributes (native JavaScript arrays) (vertices, normals, texCoords, indices) and a
prop to indicate how to interpret those vertices and normals as actual geometries.
There are several basic geometry classes predefined in luma.gl:
. They are all subclasses of the
Corresponding to those geometry objects, luma.gl also provides commonly used
classes that consist of basic geometries. These include
Users are encouraged to write their own geometries and models and luma.gl could include them in its future releases.
